plant.description: Brief Description: Leek (Allium porrum) is a vegetable in the onion family. It is a bulbous plant with broad, flat leaves.

basics.description: Brief Description: Leek (Allium porrum) is a vegetable in the onion family. It is a bulbous plant with broad, flat leaves.

toxins.name: N-propyl disulfide (also referred to generally as organosulfur compounds or sulfur compounds)
toxins.description:
in cats:
    ◦ Oxidative Damage: These compounds cause oxidative damage to the cat's red blood cells.
    ◦ Heinz Body Formation: This damage leads to the formation of Heinz bodies (clumps of denatured hemoglobin) within the red blood cells.
    ◦ Hemolysis: The damaged cells are prematurely removed and destroyed by the spleen (a process called hemolysis). This results in hemolytic anemia, a condition where the blood can no longer effectively transport oxygen.
4. Notes on
toxins.concentration_notes:
◦ Risk Level: Leeks are classified as having a "Moderate to High" potential risk for toxicity.
    ◦ Preparation: The plants remain toxic regardless of preparation; leeks are dangerous whether they are raw, cooked, dehydrated, or powdered.
    ◦ Susceptibility: Cats are noted to be more susceptible to Allium toxicity than dogs due to their unique hemoglobin structure.• Clinical Perspectives on Feline Phytotoxicology: A Comprehensive Analysis of Botanical Hazards in Domestic and Horticultural Environments12

symptoms.name: Vomiting, Diarrhea, Abdominal Pain, and Inappetence (Loss of Appetite)
symptoms.onset: Can occur early, but general poisoning signs may not appear for several days after ingestion.
symptoms.notes: Gastrointestinal irritation is often the first sign of toxicity. Drooling and nausea may also be present.Hemolytic Anemia (Pale Gums & Dark Urine)

symptoms.name: Pale or White Gums (Mucous Membranes), Dark/Reddish Urine (Hemoglobinuria), and Jaundice (Yellowing of skin/gums)
symptoms.onset: Delayed; symptoms typically manifest several days following ingestion.
symptoms.notes: Leek toxins cause oxidative damage resulting in "Heinz bodies" on red blood cells, leading to their destruction (hemolysis). Dark urine is caused by hemoglobin being filtered through the kidneys, which can lead to renal damage.Respiratory Distress

symptoms.name: Rapid Breathing (Tachypnea), Difficulty Breathing (Dyspnea), or Panting
symptoms.onset: Delayed; appears as anemia progresses (typically days after exposure).
symptoms.notes: This is a compensatory mechanism; the cat breathes rapidly to compensate for the decreased oxygen-carrying capacity of their damaged red blood cells.Cardiac Stress

symptoms.name: Rapid Heartbeat (Tachycardia)
symptoms.notes: Similar to respiratory distress, the heart beats faster to try to circulate oxygenated blood more efficiently despite the anemia.Generalized Weakness

symptoms.name: Lethargy, Weakness, Stumbling (Ataxia), and Collapse
symptoms.onset: Delayed; often several days after ingestion.
symptoms.notes: Affected cats may seek out warm spaces due to poor circulation and metabolism. Severe weakness can progress to collapse.

treatments.name: Induction of Emesis (Vomiting) and Administration of Activated Charcoal
treatments.description: If the ingestion was recent (typically within a few hours), the veterinarian will administer medication to induce vomiting, removing the leeks from the stomach before the toxins are fully absorbed. This is often followed by activated charcoal, which binds to remaining toxins in the gastrointestinal tract to prevent them from entering the bloodstream.
treatments.notes: You should never attempt to induce vomiting at home (e.g., using hydrogen peroxide) without veterinary supervision, as this can cause severe irritation or aspiration pneumonia. Decontamination is most effective when performed early.Intravenous (IV) Fluid Therapy

treatments.name: Fluid Support / Diuresis
treatments.description: The administration of IV fluids helps maintain hydration, correct electrolyte imbalances caused by vomiting or diarrhea, and supports kidney function.
treatments.notes: This step is critical because hemolytic anemia releases free hemoglobin into the bloodstream, which is filtered by the kidneys. High levels of hemoglobin can damage the kidneys (hemoglobinuria), and fluid therapy helps flush these breakdown products out of the system safely.Oxygen Therapy

treatments.name: Supplemental Oxygen
treatments.description: If the cat is experiencing difficulty breathing or low oxygen levels due to the destruction of red blood cells, they may be placed in an oxygen cage or given oxygen via a mask.
treatments.notes: Leek toxicity destroys red blood cells, reducing the blood's ability to carry oxygen. Affected cats often exhibit rapid breathing (tachypnea) or panting as they struggle to get enough oxygen to their tissues.Blood Transfusion

treatments.name: Whole Blood or Packed Red Blood Cell Transfusion
treatments.description: In severe cases where the red blood cell count (hematocrit) drops to critically low levels, a blood transfusion may be required to replace the destroyed cells and restore the cat's ability to transport oxygen.
treatments.notes: This intervention is reserved for life-threatening cases of anemia. Symptoms of severe anemia include pale or white gums, extreme lethargy, and collapse.
